title: A Practical Synthesis of the TGFβRI Inhibitor N‑(4-(3-(6-(Difluoromethyl)pyridin-2-yl)‑1H‑pyrrolo[3,2‑b]pyridin-2-yl)pyridin-2-yl)acetamide via One-Pot Sequential Sonogashira and Cacchi Reactions Catalyzed by Pd(OAc)2/BINAP

reactions.text: The discovery synthesis of 5 was accomplished in three steps starting from N-(4-ethynylpyridin-2-yl)acetamide (1) and 2-bromopyridin-3-ylamine (6), as depicted in Scheme 1. The traditional Pd/Cu-catalyzed Sonogashira cross-coupling of acetylene 1 with bromide 6 yielded bis-heteroaryl alkyne 7, which was converted to trifluoroacetamide 3 upon treatment with trifluoroacetic anhydride. A Cacchi reaction of 3 with 2-bromo-6-(difluoromethyl)pyridine (4) afforded 5.

The discovery synthesis of 5 was accomplished in three steps starting from N-(4-ethynylpyridin-2-yl)acetamide (1) and 2-bromopyridin-3-ylamine (6), as depicted in Scheme 1. The traditional Pd/Cu-catalyzed Sonogashira cross-coupling of acetylene 1 with bromide 6 yielded bis-heteroaryl alkyne 7, which was converted to trifluoroacetamide 3 upon treatment with trifluoroacetic anhydride. A Cacchi reaction of 3 with 2-bromo-6-(difluoromethyl)pyridine (4) afforded 5.

Ideally, the optimum conditions should have the following requirements for the reaction pathway, as illustrated in Scheme 3: (1) the Cu-free Sonogashira reaction of 1 with 2 should proceed to completion at a good rate; (2) the intermediate alkyne 3 should be stable under the reaction conditions with the formation of only a limited amount of the hydroamidation side product 8; and (3) the oxidation adduct 9 should rapidly form from 4 and react with 3 to give 10, which then undergoes reductive elimination to yield the deisred product 5. Although the optimization of Pd-catalyzed Sonogashira and Cacchi reactions involves many parameters, including metal precatalysts, ligands, additives, solvents, and temperatures, with the objective of rapidly developing a scalable process to provide the material required for preclinical studies, we conducted a ligand screen with the hope that optimizing this single parameter would provide a viable and reliable procedure.

Ideally, the optimum conditions should have the following requirements for the reaction pathway, as illustrated in Scheme 3: (1) the Cu-free Sonogashira reaction of 1 with 2 should proceed to completion at a good rate; (2) the intermediate alkyne 3 should be stable under the reaction conditions with the formation of only a limited amount of the hydroamidation side product 8; and (3) the oxidation adduct 9 should rapidly form from 4 and react with 3 to give 10, which then undergoes reductive elimination to yield the deisred product 5. Although the optimization of Pd-catalyzed Sonogashira and Cacchi reactions involves many parameters, including metal precatalysts, ligands, additives, solvents, and temperatures, with the objective of rapidly developing a scalable process to provide the material required for preclinical studies, we conducted a ligand screen with the hope that optimizing this single parameter would provide a viable and reliable procedure.

Ideally, the optimum conditions should have the following requirements for the reaction pathway, as illustrated in Scheme 3: (1) the Cu-free Sonogashira reaction of 1 with 2 should proceed to completion at a good rate; (2) the intermediate alkyne 3 should be stable under the reaction conditions with the formation of only a limited amount of the hydroamidation side product 8; and (3) the oxidation adduct 9 should rapidly form from 4 and react with 3 to give 10, which then undergoes reductive elimination to yield the deisred product 5. Although the optimization of Pd-catalyzed Sonogashira and Cacchi reactions involves many parameters, including metal precatalysts, ligands, additives, solvents, and temperatures, with the objective of rapidly developing a scalable process to provide the material required for preclinical studies, we conducted a ligand screen with the hope that optimizing this single parameter would provide a viable and reliable procedure.

The reaction was completed in 3 h at 90 °C with a 95:5 ratio of product 3 to side product 8, and the homocoupling product was not detected. The performance of PPh3 and X-Phos as ligands in this screen was consistent with the initial attempts discussed above, while all of the other ligands gave either significant amounts of side product 8 or slow reactions. In a control experiment conducted on a gram scale under a N2 atmosphere, heating the BINAP reaction at 100 °C in an oil bath for 3 h led to a 21% yield of 8, while continued heating for an additional hour led to an increased amount of 8 (28%), indicating that controlling the temperature plays a significant role in limiting the formation of 8. At 80–83 °C for 16 h, the reaction proceeded both smoothly and cleanly to give 3 in 87% yield along with 8 in 13% yield. With satisfactory Cu-free Sonogashira conditions in hand, attention was turned to an examination of the Cacchi reaction. After the formation of 3, 1.2 equiv of 4 was added, and the reaction was monitored. At 80 °C, the reaction proceeded slowly; however, when the temperature was raised to 90 °C, the reaction was complete in 2 h. LCMS analysis showed an 80% yield of product 5 along with a 20% yield of side product 8. These reaction conditions reproducibly produced 5 at scales of tens of grams. It should be mentioned that because of a limited supply of high-quality racemic BINAP, (S)-BINAP was used for the large-scale preparations. The use of a 1:2 molar ratio of Pd(OAc)2 and (S)-BINAP and a lower catalyst loading resulted in incomplete reactions.
